quote: Definitely Cardassian.
And in trouble.  Its engines are    completely disabled.
Open a hailing frequency.       This is Commander Sisko of Deep Space    Nine.  Do you need assistance?
They're not answering.       Their life-support systems are    operating on reserve power.
Better lock on a tractor beam and    pull them into Docking Bay Seven.     Notify Chief O'Brien to meet me there.
I'm Benjamin Sisko, commander of    Deep Space Nine.       My chief of operations, Miles O'Brien.       Do any of you need medical assistance?
I think we're all in good shape,    considering.  I'm Professor Natima    Lang.    (indicates the other     Cardassians)   These are two of my students, Rekelen    and Hogue.
What happened to your ship?
We were caught in a meteor swarm.     I'm a decent teacher, but I'm afraid    I'm not much of a shuttle pilot.       Do you think you'll be able to repair    our ship?
I'll have to take a look.  Excuse    me.
We'd like to be on our way as soon    as possible.  We know having    Cardassians on a Bajoran station may    cause trouble.  That's the last thing    we want.
If anyone can fix your ship, it's    Mister O'Brien.  In the meantime,    you're welcome to stay here.  If you    stick to the Promenade, I'm sure    there won't be any trouble.
Are you saying you agree with General    Yiri's decision to execute his    brother?
Of course I agree.  Yiri's brother    was a traitor to the Trelonian    government.
But the evidence is all    circumstantial.
My dear Doctor... it all comes down    to a question of loyalty.  Yiri had    to choose between protecting his    brother or protecting the state.  He    chose the state... as would I, every    time.
I suppose that's one way of looking    at it.  Then again, "Before you can    be loyal to another, you must be    loyal to yourself."
And who can we thank for those    misguided words of wisdom?  Sarek of    Vulcan?
Actually, it was Julian Bashir of    Earth.  And it's not too bad    considering I just made it up on the    spot.
With sentiments like those, you    wouldn't last five seconds on    Cardassia.
Would you?
Fishing again, Doctor?
Well, assuming you're not a spy...
Assuming.
Then maybe you're an outcast?
Or maybe I'm an outcast spy?
How could you be both?
I never said I was either.
I heard an interesting rumor.
Only one?  I started at least twelve.
Rumor has it you've managed to get    your hands on a small cloaking device.
And you believe everything you hear?
When it's about you, yes.       According to Bajoran law, such a    device would be highly illegal.
If I had one.  Which I don't.
I didn't expect you to admit it.     I'm simply serving notice:  You try    to sell it and I'll see to it that    you spend the next fifty years digging    trenches in a penal colony.
(winces at the     prospect, but:)   I told you... you have nothing to    worry about, because...
Excuse me.
Natima?
Quark.
I knew you'd come b...
I told you never to speak to me again.
Are you all right?
All right?       This is the happiest day of my life.
Natima, wait.  At least let me buy    you and your friends a drink.  I    could make you a Samarian Sunset.
I don't drink Samarian Sunsets    anymore.
Why not?
Because they remind me of you.
Is this...       Ferengi bothering you?
This Ferengi happens to be Natima's    old and cherished friend.  Who are    you?
These are my students.

Students.  You don't say.       You know, she always told me she    wanted to teach one day.       And now, you're doing it.     Congratulations.  It's so rare for    someone to actually achieve their    dreams.
Professor Lang isn't simply a teacher.     She's our inspiration.
Really?  I'd love to sit in on one    of your classes.  What do you teach?
Political Ethics.
Her teachings will change the future    of Cardassia.
That's enough, Rekelen.
Not at all.  I want to hear more.
I always knew that Natima was destined    for greatness.
Quark...
Just one drink.  It'll be like old    times.
It'll never be like old times.
You're right.       It'll be better.
I'll be right back with    refreshments.
Your hands are shaking.
So how well does this woman know    you?  Just enough to dislike you, or    well enough to really hate you.
She used to work here at the station.     She was a correspondent for the    Cardassian information service.  It    was before your time.
So which is it... dislike or hate?
It's none of your business, but if    you have to know... I was the love    of her life.
Must have been some life.
What about our drinks?
If you want a drink, the bar's right    over there.
Your Samarian Sunset.
(there's no force     behind her anger)   I said I didn't drink these anymore.
Because they remind you of me.  But    since I'm here anyway, you may as    well enjoy yourself.  Besides, it's    on the house.
You know, you're as beautiful as    ever.
And you're as big a liar as ever.
You see... just like old times.       I've missed you, Natima.  And that's    no lie.
(looking around the     bar)   You seem to have kept busy.
Oh, yes.  I'm very successful.  But    as the two hundred and twenty-third    Rule of Acquisition says...

Please.  I haven't heard a Rule of    Acquisition in seven years.  And I    don't want to hear one now.       You never apologized, Quark.  You    never admitted you were wrong.  I    think that hurt more than anything.
Would it really have made any    difference?
Maybe not.  But it would've been    nice if you'd tried.
All right.  I'm sorry.  I was wrong.
It's too late.
It's never too late.       So how long are you going to be on    the station?
Thank you for another enjoyable lunch.     Doctor.
I didn't think there'd be any    Cardassians left on the station.
He's the only one.
What do we do now?
Why?  Is something wrong?
We have to leave... as soon as    possible.       Goodbye, Quark.  Thanks for the drink.
But you didn't touch it.
How are your repairs coming?
The damage is more extensive than I    thought.       They were lucky to survive the attack.
The attack?
They weren't in any meteor swarm.     Their ship was hit by Cardassian    disrupters.
That doesn't make sense.  Why would    Cardassians fire on other Cardassians?
Maybe you should ask her.
I hate to be an imposition, Commander,    but I need my ship.
That's not possible.  Mister O'Brien    is still working on it.       Your ship sustained more damage than    we originally thought, in fact...
You suspect our ship was damaged by    Cardassian weapons.  You're right, of    course.
Professor...
It's all right, Hogue.  I should've    told them the truth in the first    place.
Then why didn't you?
Because Cardassians don't involve    outsiders in their internal politics.     Especially Bajorans.
Being shot at by your own people    goes a little beyond politics.
We take our politics very seriously.       Commander, if I don't get my students    to safety they're going to be killed.     And if they die, the future of    Cardassia may die with them.
To put it simply, not everyone inside    the Cardassian Empire is satisfied    with the way the Central Command    governs.
Not everyone outside, either.
There are some who believe the future    of Cardassia shouldn't remain in the    hands of the military.
And you're among them?
Yes, we are.
Rekelen and Hogue are two of the    most important leaders of our    movement.
Which makes you fugitives.
The military's afraid to let us speak    our minds.

We only want a better future for all    Cardassians.  A future based on peace    and non-violence.       But if we achieve peace, true peace,    both inside and outside our borders,    the military will no longer be able    to justify their control of the    Empire.
Military governments are notoriously    reluctant to give up power.
Ours is no exception.
They've already tried to kill us    once... they're sure to try again.
Which is why I have to get them off    this station... as soon as possible.
I'll dispatch additional work crews    to help repair your ship.
The sooner the better, Commander.
We saw another Cardassian aboard the    station... in the bar.
Garak?  He saw you?
I'm certain of it.
Then... we may have a problem.  Mister    Garak is a bit of a mystery to us.     One of my officers is convinced he    works for Cardassian Intelligence.     For all I know he could be right.
Why don't you arrest him?
On what charge?
You're the commander.  You don't    need a reason.
That's not how we do things here.
Nor should it be.
I'll assign you some guest quarters.     You'll be safe there until your ship    is ready.
We appreciate your assistance,    Commander.
Mister Quark, this is a surprise.  I    don't believe you've ever been in my    establishment before.
You usually don't frequent mine,    either... though I did see you in    there today.
The Replimat was a little crowded.     So what brings you here now?
Oh, I just wanted to see what you're    offering.
What do you get for this?
Seventeen strips of latinum.
Tell you what, I'll give you twenty.
Twenty?  How uncharacteristically    generous... for a Ferengi.
Just one businessman trying to help    out another.  I figure we have to    stick together.
This is the latest style on my    homeworld.  Do you like it?
I'm no expert on Cardassian fashions.     What do you think?
I don't know.  It's been so long    since I've had a Cardassian customer.
Then you're in luck.  There're some    on the station right now.
Now that you mention it, I think    your lady friend may find this style    very appealing.  You are old friends,    aren't you?
You're very perceptive, for a    Cardassian.
It would've been hard to miss the    way you were looking at her.
It would've been hard to miss the    way you were looking at her.
I always try to observe the fashions    of visitors to the station.
Personally I find this style a bit    too radical, but your friend seems    the type who appreciates that sort    of thing.
Different tastes for different people.       Nothing wrong with that, is there?

You'd be surprised how detrimental a    poor choice of fashion can be.  Take    this dress.  It may be all the rage    now... but it could quickly become    tiresome, an affront to the eyes.     Certain people may even find it...    objectionable.  And then...       Nothing but rags.
I see.
Mister Quark, may I offer you some    free advice?
As long as I'm under no obligation    to follow it.
I've been in this business a long    time.

And I know there's nothing worse    than following the wrong trend.  Now    you're a smart fellow.    (glances at Quark's     clothing)   With your own inimitable style.     Perhaps you should mention that to    your lady friend.  I'd hate to see    her become... a victim of fashion.
Would you like to explain that?
She's chosen to associate herself    with some rather flamboyant    companions.  It would be a tragedy    if she got in the way when her    friends... went out of style.
(no longer dancing     around)   If anyone tries to hurt her, they're    going to have to deal with me.
What're you going to do?  Shortchange    them at the dabo table?
I think I'll buy this dress after    all.  See that it's mended.
Professor, we have to do    something.
If you want to do something    constructive, stop pacing... the    both of you.
We can't just sit here while    everything we've worked for is    slipping away.
Have faith.  Your work is just    beginning.
How can you say that?  The movement    is in shambles... we're fleeing for    our lives... the military's hold is    stronger than ever.  Things are no    better than when we started.
That's not true.  Look at all you've    accomplished.  Five years ago there    was no hope for progress.  The    military's rule wasn't even    questioned.  That's all changed now.
We could never have done it without    your support.
What we've started can't be undone.     Don't you see, they can kill me...    they can kill you, but they can't    kill our ideas... our hope for a    better Cardassia.
(worried, but putting     up a good front)   You're right, Professor.

Don't worry, Hogue.  I have no    intention of letting you become    martyrs.  I'll get you out of this    somehow.    (venting her own     frustration)   If we could only get to Sadera Six    and join up with the others...
(Quark's voice,     disguised)   Lieutenant Smith to Professor Lang.     Commander Sisko is on his way to    your quarters.  He'd like to speak    to you in private.
Thank you.  I'll be waiting.       Why don't you two go see if Chief    O'Brien's made any progress with our    ship?
Enter.
Quark.  I can't talk now.  I'm    expecting Commander Sisko.
He's not coming.
What do you mean he's not coming?
Trust me.
Lieutenant Smith?
At your service.
You haven't changed a bit.
You're wrong, Natima.  I haven't    been the same since you left.
What is it you want from me?
I know you're in trouble.  I want to    help you.
I don't want your help.
But I owe you.  You saved my life.     If you had turned me over to the    authorities, I'd've been executed.
I admired your courage.  It was a    brave thing you were doing... selling    food to the Bajorans.  I thought you    were a man of honor.
I'm a Ferengi.  You should've known    better.
You're right.  I should have.     Instead...
Can't you even say it?
I can't even think it.
Okay, then I'll say it for you.  We    fell in love.  And that month we    spent together was the best time of    our lives... and you know it.
I think you're confusing lust with    love.
I admit... I'm capable of it.  But    not this time.  I loved you, Natima.
Then how could you have betrayed me?
I didn't betray you.
Don't lie to me, Quark.  I know    better.  You used my personal access    codes to authorize payments for goods    you never provided.
So I took a little money from the    Cardassian Communication Service.     They could afford it.
You stole that money.
I saw a chance for profit and I took    it.  Maybe that was wrong.  I don't    know.  But what I really regret was    betraying your trust.       That was the worst mistake of my    life.
And you'd do it again in a second.     I believed in you, Quark.  But you    were using me.  Like you use everyone.     For profit.
Then let me make it up to you.  Let    me help you.  I ask for nothing in    return.
Nothing?
Except that you'll stay with me    forever.
I can't stay here, Quark.  My students    need me.
Listen to me, Natima.  You can't    leave me.  Not now.  If you don't    stay with me, I'll have to follow    you.  And I will.  Wherever you go.     Until you agree to take me back.
Quark, you don't even know me anymore.     I'm part of the Cardassian    underground.  Following me will only    get you killed.
I'll take that chance.
What about the bar?
I don't care about the bar.  I'll    turn it over to Rom.  He'll run it    into the ground in a month, but that    doesn't matter.  I have to be with    you.
It won't work, Quark.  You say you'd    do anything for me.  Maybe right    now, you even believe it.
But I know better.  In the end, you'd    only care about yourself.
But I love you.
I don't love you.
Now which one of us is lying?
(trying not to let     him get to her)   You'd better go.
All right.  But if there's anything    you need... anything at all... I'll    be waiting.
It'll be a long wait.
Professor Lang's ship should be ready    to go in about an hour, Commander.
Good, I'll let her know.
We have a Cardassian warship    approaching.  Fast.
On screen.
Dax, hail them.
No response.
The ship's taking up an attack    posture.
They're still ignoring us.
They're powering up their forward    disrupters.
Shields!
Shields up.
Lock on phasers and photon    torpedoes... Prepare to return fire    if necessary.
Commander?       We need to talk.
All right, Garak, you mind telling    me why a Cardassian warship is    threatening my station?
No one is threatening you.  The    Central Command merely wants to make    sure that they have your undivided    attention.
Well, they have it.  I assume this    has something to do with Professor    Lang and her students?
"Students" is a rather benign term    for them.  "Terrorists" would be    more accurate.  The Cardassian    government would very much like Hogue    and Rekelen returned home immediately.
They haven't committed any crimes    here.  As long as they're on my    station, they're free to do whatever    they want.
This is all very embarrassing,    Commander.  The Central Command would    hate to see the Federation pulled    into such an insignificant and purely    internal affair.
I would hardly call it insignificant.     Judging from the behavior of that    ship out there, it appears the Central    Command considers Hogue and Rekelen    to be extremely dangerous.
Not at all.  Annoying, perhaps.     Inconvenient, maybe.  But dangerous?     Hardly.  If they were dangerous,    would the Central Command entrust    the situation to me, a simple tailor?
Which only confirms what I've    suspected all along.  You, Mister    Garak, are no simple tailor.
Really, Commander, that's another    discussion, entirely.  All you need    to know right now is that the return    of Hogue and Rekelen is in the best    interests of the Cardassian Empire.
Or at least in the best interest of    the Cardassian military.
Is there a difference?
Do you really expect a Bajoran    station, under Federation command,    to turn over Cardassian political    refugees... on your say-so?
The ultimate decision is yours of    course.  I'm simply relaying a    message.
Then relay this.  Tell the Central    Command that if anyone attempts to    take Hogue and Rekelen by force, I    will respond in kind.  Am I clear,    Mister Garak?
Absolutely.  Thank you for your time.
Here, you go.  Two mugs of Kanar...    on the house.
We didn't order these.
They're the drinks I promised you    the first time you were in here.     Sorry they took so long but things    have been a little hectic.       Do you mind?
I'm afraid we do.
Professor Lang told us you couldn't    be trusted.
You Cardassians do hold grudges.     Seven years ago Natima and I had    some silly lovers' quarrel and...    Well, all I can say is... I'm willing    to let bygones be bygones.
But Professor Lang isn't.
I have to say I find your loyalty to    her extremely touching.
There's nothing we wouldn't do for    her.  And if she says not to talk to    you, then we don't talk to you.
I understand.  She's your teacher...    you're her students... you have to    listen to her.
So, if you don't want to talk to the    only person who can get you off this    station in one piece, that's fine    with me.
Wait.
You say you can help us get away?
It's possible.
How?
One second.
The station's security chief's a    shape-shifter.  You can never be    too careful.    (moving closer to     speak in confidence)   I take it you know what a cloaking    device is?
Well, I have one.  It's not in the    best of condition... but it'll work    for about fifteen minutes.  Long    enough to get you away from here.
Sounds expensive.
We don't have much in the way of    latinum, but whatever we do have is    yours.
Exactly how much latinum are we    talking about?
Forget I said that.  I don't want    your money.  Consider the cloaking    device a gift.
I'm surprised.  Ferengis aren't known    for their generosity.
We're a deeply misunderstood race.
You may've saved our lives.  Our    movement owes you a debt of gratitude.
And I know exactly how you can repay    me.       You have to convince Natima to stay    here.
Would you please stop doing that.
The Professor will never agree to    stay behind.
No Natima... no cloaking device and    no way off this station.
She won't do it.
You'll have to talk her into it.     After all, you're the ones the    Cardassians are after.
He's right.  She shouldn't have to    risk her life for our crimes.
I suppose we could ask her.
Don't ask her.  Tell her.
We'll do our best.
I'm sure you will.  I shudder to    think what would happen if the    military gets its hands on you.
Meet us at our quarters in an hour.
I'll be there.
Come in.
Where are Rekelen and Hogue?
They're waiting at the ship.
Perfect.       I know my quarters might seem a little    crowded at first, but tomorrow    morning, I'll put in a request for    something bigger.
That won't be necessary.
All right, if you want your own    quarters to start out with, I can    arrange that, too.
I mean I'm not staying.
Now hold on.  Your students and I    had an agreement.  They get the    cloaking device...    (indicates the object     under his arm)   And you stay with me.  That way    everyone's happy.
Quark, you say you love me... then    give me the cloaking device and let    me be on my way.
And let you disappear out of my life    again?
I'm not a part of your life, Quark.
But you are.  You always have been.
Don't you understand, since you left    me, not a day goes by that I don't    regret what I did.  And now you're    asking me to lose you again.
You lost me a long time ago.
All right, then say it... let me    hear you say that there isn't a spark    of love left in you.
There isn't a spark of love left in    me.
I heard that.
What?
You hesitated.  Admit it, you still    care.
Quark, I don't have time for this.     Give me that cloaking device.
I can't.  I won't let you go.
I didn't want to have to get it this    way, but I need that device... Give    it to me.  Now.
Or what?  You'll shoot me?
If I have to.
Then go ahead and shoot.
Quark... Quark, are you all right.
(still doesn't believe     it)   You shot me.
I didn't mean to.  It was an accident.    (holding up the gun     for Quark to see)   I never fired a phaser before.  I    barely touched the trigger...
Careful.
Owww.
It hurts?
She wants to know if it hurts?       Of course it hurts.  It's supposed    to hurt.  It's a phaser.
I made sure it was only on the first    setting.
How considerate of you.
Should I get a doctor?
That's okay.  Maybe if you rub it a    little.
Oh, Quark... I'm sorry.
Really?
Yes, for everything... all those    horrible things I said...
You really didn't mean them?
I love you, Quark.  I've always loved    you.  Even when I hated you.
Natima.
I've missed you... I've missed you    so much.  Being with you was the    happiest time of my life.
And now we're together again, and we    have the rest of our lives to be    happy.
I wish it was that easy.
But it can be... if you let it.
I'm not the same person I was seven    years ago.  I have responsibilities...
I'll share them with you.
The movement is my life now.  I don't    have time for anything else.
We'll make the time.  You're a woman,    Natima.  Believe me, I know.  And    it's not right for you to be alone.
I'm not alone.  I have my students...    my dreams of a better Cardassia.
But are dreams enough?  Can dreams    make you laugh?  Can dreams hold you    close at night?
No.  But my life demands that I make    certain sacrifices...
And you've made them.  But that    doesn't mean you can't be happy.
We did have fun together, didn't we?
Remember the day I installed my first    holosuite.
I'd never been in one before.
I still have that program... the    picnic on Rhymus Major.  Two suns in    the sky...
The sound of the waterfalls.
The whisper of flitterbird wings    over our heads...
You painted my face with honey...
And a Mordian butterfly landed on    your nose...
A Mordian butterfly got stuck on my    nose.
His wings were beating almost as    fast as my heart.
Those were good times.
The best.  And we can have them back    again.  I'll give the cloaking device    to your students.  Once they're gone,    you'll be safe, and we can be    together.
I can't just abandon them, Quark.     They need me.
I need you.  Don't you see, Natima,    you've done enough for the movement.     You lit the match.  Now let them    carry the torch.
Or are you saying the movement won't    survive without you?
Of course it will.
Then let it.  And let us have the    happiness we deserve.
You really do love me, don't you?
With all that I am, Natima.     Forever.
Will you stay?
Yes, Quark.  I'll stay.
You don't know how I've waited to    hear that.
Enter.
Professor Lang?
Not now, Odo.  Can't you see we're    busy?
I apologize for the interruption,    but I'm afraid, madam... You're under    arrest.
I'm... what?
On what charge?
Commander Sisko will explain.       I am truly sorry.
Now hold on.
It's all right, Quark.
Commander, would you please explain    what we're doing here?
I'm afraid the three of you are going    to be turned over to the Cardassian    government.
You can't do that.
I wish I didn't have to.  But    Cardassia has offered to hand over a    half-dozen Bajoran prisoners in    exchange for you.
And you've agreed to this?
The Bajoran Provisional Government    agreed to it.
A Cardassian transport will deliver    the Bajoran prisoners in a little    over five hours.
Commander, you have no idea what    they're going to do to us.
We're the ones they're after.  At    least let Professor Lang go.

I'd like nothing better.  But the    provisional government has ordered    that you all be turned over.  I'm    fighting this every way I can... and    I'm not ready to give up yet.  I'm    due to address the Chamber of    Ministers on subspace in half an    hour.  I'll do everything I can to    convince them that they're wrong.       But in the end... this is a Bajoran    station, and I have to abide by their    decision.  No matter how much I    disagree with it.
How the mighty have fallen.
Toran.
It's Gul Toran now.
They've made you a Gul.  I didn't    realize the situation on Cardassia    had gotten so desperate.
I find your bitterness extremely...    gratifying.  I'm glad to see that    you're adjusting so poorly to exile.
Actually, I'm finding my time here    to be most illuminating.
Then I don't suppose you'd be    interested in going home again?
Am I to be rewarded for informing    the Central Command about Hogue and    Rekelen's presence on the station?
Perhaps.  But only after you see to    it that they don't leave this station    alive.
But I suggested a prisoner exchange...    the Central Command agreed...
I convinced them otherwise.
They listened to you?
My voice is less tarnished than yours.
Kill them and all you'll be creating    are martyrs.
You overestimate their importance.
So how do you propose to arrange    this unfortunate incident?

I'm sure you'll think of something.     You always did in the past.       Don't you see?  Lang's death will    benefit us both.  Unless of course,    you intend to spend the rest of your    life as a tailor.
I see your point.
I knew you would.
Odo, we have to talk.
I'm busy.  Come back later.
Later will be too late.
"I, the Jury" by Mickey Spillane?
Chief O'Brien loaned it to me.
This had better be important, Quark.
It is.  Odo, you have to let Natima    and her students go.
Do I?
Those students could be the key to a    new Cardassia.  A Cardassia free    from military rule and oppression.
Since when have you become so    interested in Cardassian politics?
A freer more open society on Cardassia    would benefit this entire sector...       And it'd be great for business.
So wanting me to free Natima and    those students is strictly a financial    consideration on your part?
Now, Odo... Don't allow my greed to    keep you from doing the right thing.
I know you better than you think,    Quark.  This isn't about Cardassia.     And for once, it isn't even about    profit.       This is about Professor Lang.
You're right.  It is.  Her life is    in jeopardy as long as Rekelen and    Hogue are on the station.
Why didn't you tell me that before.

What was I supposed to say?  That I    love her?  That I'd do anything for    her?  That without her, my life would    be meaningless?       Sure I could say that, but what good    would it do?  How could I expect you    to understand?  You've never had    those feelings.  You don't know what    it means to really care about another    person.  You've never been in love.     You've got all the emotions of a    stone.       No offense.
Go on.

Listen to me, Odo, you do this for    me, and I promise you... there will    be no more secrets between us.  I    will tell you about every underhanded    deal... every lying scheme... every    dirty trick... my brother Rom's    involved in.
Well when you put it that way... I'm    not interested.
Okay, let me put it another way.  Do    it for me...
For you?

That's right.  For all the years    we've known each other... for    everything we've been through    together.  You say you know me better    than anyone... well, I know you.     Sure sometimes we're on opposite    sides, but that doesn't mean we aren't    close.  I've never told you this,    Odo, but I consider you as dear to    me as my brother.
And I've seen how well you treat    him.
Odo, look at me.  I'm on my knees...    I'm begging you.  I don't care why    you do it... pick any reason you    want.  But please, let Natima and    the others go.
All right.  I'll do it.
You will.
But not for you.  Turning Hogue and    Rekelen over to the Cardassians will
Justice... that was going to be my    next suggestion.       So, you're really not doing this for    me?
That's right.
Then I don't owe you a thing.  Thank    you.
You'll never know how much this means    to me.
Let go.
I'm sorry.  Now let's hurry before    you change your mind.
Just one question.  How do you expect    Rekelen and Hogue to get past that    warship?       I knew you had a cloaking device.
I always said you were too smart for    me, Odo.
Quark.  What are you doing here?
Getting you out.
Thank you.
Good luck.

I've installed the cloaking device    in your central engine core.  You    can activate it from the bridge as    soon as the mooring clamps are    released.  Then I suggest you take    your ship to warp eight and don't    look back.
(continuing, to all     of them)   Now please, make your good-byes    brief.
What's the rush?
You've betrayed us.
No.
Don't.  I'd hate to ruin such a nice    suit.
Why are you doing this?
Exile tends to wear thin after a    while, even when the surroundings    are as pleasant as these.
Fine.  Take them, but leave Natima    alone.
Quark.
No.  He's right.  We're the fugitives,    not you.
You see, they agree with me.
Unfortunately, it's not their decision    to make.  Nor mine.  Professor Lang,    however minor her role in this matter,    has come to the attention of the    Central Command.
Do you think killing us is going to    change anything?  Cardassia is    slipping out of the military's grasp.     And nothing you do can prevent it.
Madam, I am not here to debate you.
Garak, if you harm these people,    I'll see to it that Commander Sisko    prosecutes you to the fullest extent    of the law.
Which brings up another issue.  Quark,    things would've been much simpler if    you'd taken my advice and not gotten    involved with these people.
I was already involved.
I know.  A pity, really.  Personally,    I rather like you, Quark.
You mean, you're going to shoot me    too.
Before I became a tailor, I lived by    a simple motto:  "Never allow    sentiment to interfere with your    work."  A bit of a cliche, but true    nonetheless.
I'll keep that in mind.
Well, then... Though I admit it's    against my better judgement, I'm    afraid I must carry out the verdict    of the Central Command.
But you admit that they're wrong.     Why don't you stand up for what you    believe in?
More to the point...
What do you believe in, Garak?
What are you doing here, Toran?
Making sure that you carry out your    assignment.  I suspected that two    years living among Bajorans would    make you soft.  I see I was right.
You've never been right about    anything, Toran.  Now step aside and    let me finish this sorry business.
I'll take over from here.
Why?  So you can take the credit and    make sure I remain in disgrace.
I can't believe that you were once    considered clever.
Did you really think that completing    this one simple task would restore    your reputation with the Central    Command?
I suppose not.
Go back to your sewing kit, tailor.
Some people should never be promoted.
(continuing, to Hogue     and Rekelen)   Well, don't just stand there.  Your    ship's waiting.
I'm going to see to it that every    Ferengi on the station shops at your    store.
That alone makes this all worthwhile.
You heard the man.  Get moving.
Thank you... both of you.
Yes, yes, yes.  Now go.  Quickly.     And keep up the good work.
Quark, I've got to say good-bye.
Just let them go.  It'll be less    painful that way.
You don't understand.  I have to say    good-bye... to you.  I'm going with    them.
But we had a deal.
I can't stay here.  Maybe one day, I    can come back, and we'll be together    again.  But not until my work is    done.
So all I have to do to get you back    is wait until Cardassia becomes a    free and democratic society.
I promise, I'll make it worth the    wait.
I don't suppose I could come with    you.

No.  It's not your fight.  And I    could never live with myself if    something happened to you.  I need    to know that you're here, safe.     That way, part of me will always be    safe, too.       I love you, Quark.  I always will.
I love you, too.
I suggest we return to the Promenade    without delay.
You have to tell me... why'd you do    it?  Shoot Toran?
Why did you let Professor Lang go?
I had no choice.  I love her.
And I love Cardassia.  Which is why    I had to do what I did.
I don't understand.
That's the thing about love.  No one    really understands it, do they?
